questions.text: A strong $\mathbf{thesis \, statement}$ must be $\mathbf{debatable}$ or $\mathbf{arguable}$, meaning it $\mathbf{...}$?

options.a: Is a simple, universally accepted fact
options.b: Presents an opinion or argument that requires proof
options.c: Must be exactly three sentences long

questions.text: In $\mathbf{academic \, writing}$, citing an external source using a specific format (e.g., $\text{APA, \, MLA}$) is known as $\mathbf{...}$?
Which sentence structure contains $\mathbf{two \, or \, more \, independent \, clauses}$ and $\mathbf{one \, or \, more \, dependent \, clauses}$?
The $\mathbf{primary \, difference}$ between a $\mathbf{business \, report}$ and an $\mathbf{academic \, essay}$ lies in their $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Objective (reports solve problems/recommend action; essays argue a thesis)

questions.text: In an $\mathbf{argumentative \, essay}$, the $\mathbf{counterargument}$ section serves to $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Acknowledge and then refute opposing views

questions.text: The term for when an independent clause is followed by a series of modifying phrases or subordinate clauses is a $\mathbf{...}$ sentence.
In a $\mathbf{research \, report}$, the $\mathbf{Methodology \, section}$ explains $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: How the research was conducted (procedures, materials, etc.)

questions.text: Using $\mathbf{passive \, voice}$ ($	ext{e.g., \, 'The \, ball \, was \, thrown}$ by her') is generally discouraged in formal writing because it often $\mathbf{...}$?

options.c: Obscures the agent (who performed the action)

questions.text: The goal of $\mathbf{paragraph \, coherence}$ is to ensure that $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: All sentences flow logically and are relevant to the topic sentence

questions.text: A $\mathbf{white \, paper}$ is a type of report primarily intended to $\mathbf{...}$?

options.c: Inform readers concisely about a complex issue or solution and often advocate a position
options.d: Provide a daily log of activities

questions.text: To achieve $\mathbf{parallelism}$ in a list, all items must be in the same $\mathbf{...}$?

options.c: Grammatical form (e.g., all nouns, all gerunds)

questions.text: Which $\mathbf{logical \, fallacy}$ attacks the person making the argument instead of the argument itself?
In a $\mathbf{formal \, letter}$ of complaint, the $\mathbf{recipient's \, address}$ (inside address) should appear $\mathbf{...}$?

options.d: After the body of the letter

questions.text: The phrase $\mathbf{in \, conclusion}$ should be avoided in favor of $\mathbf{...}$?

options.a: More subtle transition phrases or logical wrapping up

questions.text: The $\mathbf{Works \, Cited}$ page in an $\text{MLA \, essay}$ is an example of a $\mathbf{...}$?
What is the function of an $\mathbf{explanatory \, footnote}$ in a report?

options.b: To provide tangential or supplementary information without disrupting the main text flow

questions.text: The $\mathbf{purpose \, of \, a \, feasibility \, report}$ is to $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Assess whether a project or plan is practical and viable

questions.text: A sentence that is grammatically correct but $\mathbf{wordy \, and \, unclear}$ suffers from a lack of $\mathbf{...}$?
When writing about literature, using the $\mathbf{historical \, present \, tense}$ (e.g., 'Hamlet $\mathbf{contemplates}$ his fate') helps establish $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: A continuous, timeless analysis of the text

questions.text: The $\mathbf{rhetorical \, situation}$ of a piece of writing involves the $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Context, audience, purpose, and author's persona
